title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHICAGO — In a defensive war of attrition where points were a precious commodity, Michael Jordan authored a masterpiece of sheer will.

In a game that defied the high-flying era, the Chicago Bulls grinded out an 81-79 victory over the Indiana Pacers, a contest less defined by the final score than by Jordan’s historic 42-point performance. On a night when the rest of his team struggled to find any offensive rhythm, His Airness was the entirety of the Bulls’ attack, accounting for over half of his team’s points in a vintage display of scoring brilliance.

The United Center held its breath with every possession, as neither team could muster a consistent run. While Reggie Miller led the Pacers with a valiant 22 points, Indiana’s effort was a collective, balanced push against the singular force of Jordan. The Bulls’ supporting cast of Scottie Pippen and Dennis Rodman combined for a mere 13 points, their value coming on the defensive end and the glass.

Yet, it was enough. Because they had Jordan.

In the game’s final, tense moments, with the outcome hanging on every shot, the ball inevitably found its way to number 23. He delivered, as he so often has, slicing through the Pacers’ defense and hitting contested jumpers with an assassin’s calm. His 42 points were not just a statistic; they were a relentless, personal refusal to lose.

In the end, the scoreboard read like a typo, a relic from a bygone era. But the story it told was timeless: Michael Jordan, against all odds, could still put an entire team on his back and carry them to victory. It was not pretty, but it was a work of art.
